COPIED

Rottnest settlement: Thomsons Bay 1900-1908. From right to left - The Pilot boats crew quarters-dining room, kitchen, etc. The opening in front was the boat shed. The Pilot took ships to Fremantle and he was later ferried back to the island. The second building was originally the Pilot's quarters, then the Signalmans and now Des Sullivan's house. The third building was semi-detached houses, the left one occupied by Chief Warder J.J. O'Donoghue on his retirement. In 1917 or 1918 O'Donoghue was transferred to the Board of Control. Another occupant was the school teacher. The fourth building was the Superintendents house. On the extreme left is the Governor's residence or Government House as the locals called it. The sea wall was built by Superintendent Vincent. 
Accession No. 43.120

Half-way Tree  in Claremont, Stirling Highway, south side opposite Vaucluse Street  

 Inscription reads "On this spot stood the Half-way Tree at which mailmen from Perth and Fremantle met and exchanged their mails from the earliest days of the colony up to 1867".
William de Vlamingh : Inscription reads "William de Vlamingh Dutch Navigator who visited this island on the 30th December 1696 and named it Rottenest Island."  Located on Rottnest.
BibliographReferences: Rottnest Board of Control and Western Australian Historical Society

ItemName: FREMANTLE, LOOKING SOUTH FROM ROUND HOUSE
Description: Fremantle, looking South From Round House

Wooden box, japanned; opens to form a velvet covered writing surface. Bottom of box has divisions for storage. Box is black with ornamentation on lid of a circle of flowers of inlaid mother of pearl surrounding a bunch of flowers, painted and inlaid mother of pearl. Provenance: Belonged to Mrs Bridges, grand-daughter of Capt Thomas who came to WA on 'Gilmore' on 10/11/1829.
One single sheet with a 7.5cm wide row of hand-crocheted lace 5.5cms from top of sheet, crocheted in design of roses and leaves and hand sewn to sheet.

Triangular cribbage board with a brass knob at each join to act as a foot.  Each side has two holes to contain pegs, covered with a strip of brass fastened with a central pin, so cover can swivel to cover holes.  Stated by donor to be 100 years old.
Dimensions: L: 27.7 cm x  W: 27.7 cm x H: 27.7 cm

ItemName: GREETING CARD WITH PAINTING OF CARNARVON DRY RIVER BED
Description:
Greeting card with painting titled 'Dry River bed near Carnarvon, W.A.' signed P Berry
Printed in green inside card 'Dry river bed near Carnarvon, WA' By Paul Berry. /Paul, paralysed in the arms by poliomyelitis, paints with his foot.
With Best Wishes/for Christmas/and the New Year
Handwritten message in black ink
MakersMarks: painting by Paul Berry for Paraplegic Association of WA
StatementOfSignificance: Representativeness: Greeting card with painting of Carnarvon done for Paraplegic Association of WA
Materials: paper, printing ink and writing ink

Description:
Post card. Nurse Pearl Ashwin in nursing uniform  Meekatharra Hospital

Printed on reverse: Image: Nurse Pearl Ashwin, Meekatharra Hospital/State Library of Western Australia, BA368/278/My Story: Pearl Ashwin was one of the first Aboriginal women in Meekatharra to become a registered nurse and is pictured here working at Meekatharra Hospital.

Storylines is a State Library initiative to explore with the community the last 125 years of Aboriginal history through our heritage collections.
StatementOfSignificance: Interpretive: Photograph of Nurse Pearl Ashwin one of the first Aboriginal women in Meekatharra to become a registered nurse
